Posts.Content: Hi Jsteph I had chemo first as tumour fairly large, 5cm, with node involvement.  Also grade 3.  They hoped it would shrink or disappear with chemo which a lot of ladies on here have had happened to them.  Then I might have for away with a lumpectomy.  Unfortunately I only had a partial response and so still need a full mastectomy, full node clearance, DIEP, and breast reduction to other side.  And they are doing all that on Wednesday all being well! Good luck with all your planning and treatment
Posts.Title: Diep

Posts.Content: Mine is scheduled for 16th Jan.  Gulp.  Trying not to think about it too much.  Had pre op on Friday and that is just general.  I got some lovely advice on what to take into hospital from the lovely people on this site.  I am expecting to be sore and be limited with what I can do for a few weeks.  But I am taking comfort that I just do this once and don't repeat every 3 weeks like the chemo did! I had chemo first. Now going to shops to buy a V pillow ....
Posts.Title: Diep

Posts.Content: Hi.  I was also advised not to travel abroard due to infection risk.  I made a successful claim on my travel insurance for the cost of the holiday.
Posts.Title: chemo & travel

Posts.Content: Oh NiceCuppa.  When we are so low we are super sensitive to what people say and how they say it.  The professionals should realise this though.  When I was in hospital with my mastectomy and DIEP a male auxillary asked me what greade cancer I had.  Grade 3 I told him.  Keep positive he said and you may not die! The trouble is he really thought he was helping  . . .  Do hope things improve for you.  I found EC much easier than Docetaxol.  Fingers crossed you do too.
Posts.Title: Fuming with comment from nurse in Chemo unit

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I have been wondering how I would get on washing my synthetic wigs.  So have taken the bull by horns and washed my NHS wig yesterday.  And it feels much better than it did when it was new!  It is softer and more natural looking.  So if anyone is concerned about how they will be - don't be.  I used the wig shampoo and conditioner I bought with my wig.  But I think some use clothes washing liquid and conditioner.  And it it is shiny and soft.  So my other longer wig is now washed and drying.
Posts.Title: Washing our wonderful wigs

Posts.Content: I brushed them before I washed them so they were tangle free.  Washed them being careful not to scrunch them up.  When they were dry I brushed them again and they looked fab.  Kept their style and looked good.
Posts.Title: Washing our wonderful wigs

Posts.Content: Hi Whitby Wjhen I was where you are no I went and had a "number 5" - about 1cm all over.  And kept rubbing it!  But I found it was easier to cope with very short.   I am chemo 5, docetaxol 2, plus 13 days.  At last I feel a bit better.  Forgotten what feeling well feels like but I am definitely better than I was this time last week! All my visitors have postponed as everyone is full of cold - but definitely dont want a cold so its a downside of this time of year.  Hopefully they all feel better soon - for their sakes.  Colds can be horrid.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi devondumpling My second chemo was my best in terms of least side effects.   Fingers crossed its good for you xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi RumCat.  We are all different with how each chemo takes us.  Some find subsequent ones easier.  When you have struggled so much some have their dosages reduced a bit and cope better.  My onco wouldn't reduce my dosage but I didn't have my last Chemo on his recommendation Keep strong.  Keep asking for things to manage the SEs.  And keep asking on here.  Someone may be able to help. Xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Bluebell22 I am doing OK thanks.  Got my surgery plan yesterday.  As i have only had a partial response to chemo I need a full mastectomy and node clearance.  So the plan is to do mastectomy and node clearance and have DIEP flap reconstruction AND reduction to good breast to balance things up to end up with a D cup on both sides all in one operation!  This planned for middle to end of January.   Still suffering with fatigue from chemo.  Last chemo 4 weeks ago.  But it is improving slowly and making sure I walk each day to try and improve stamina. The surgeon would like me to lose half a stone before op if possible.  I have put on loads of weight during chemo - comfort eating and sweet things tasting best.  So just as taste buds are beginning to recover, and Christmas, I need to watch what I eat!  Oh well - choose food carefully and keep portions small. . . . .   I was planning to lose weight after surgery so if I do some now I will be ahead of the game!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I'm in again.  Last dose of Docetaxel due on 12th.  If I recover enough from this one.   Love and hugs to everyone else in for December
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Helen K.  That blasted docetaxel- seems to leave us much more susceptible to infections.  Glad you're home.  And so sorry Christmas was in hospital.  You sound so positive - well done you.  Rest now and have some treats if you can before your next chemo.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Coley1993.  So sorry you are struggling.  You do need to talk this through with your oncologist.  My oncologist told me that as long as I had had 4 rounds of chemo he was happy.  In the end I managed 5 and then stopped.  I have had chemo before surgery.  ER positive with at least one node.  You do need to see if there is anything else they can give you to help with side effects.  But talk it through with your oncologist.  Mine did say that the Tamoxifen type drugs were the most important part of treatment apart from surgery.   Good luck with whatever you decide.  And hugs xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Oh RumCat big hugs.  It is horrid isn't it.  I'm glad you are getting some meds to help with side effects.  But they are the pits aren't they.  And taste bud problems don't help.  I found tea tasted awful for weeks and I mostly drink fruit tea now as even 5 weeks after last chemo ordinary tea can taste funny - but it is improving.  Hang in there.  The drugs should be killing the cancer. The new flat sounds lovely.  Hope that helps your spirits.  Watching the sea can be so soothing.  Always something to look at. Keep going - we are with you and sending all our good vibes to minimise those side effects.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: hitforsix, Tigermum, pinklady - me too!  Rubbish isn't it.  I keep eating all sorts trying to find somethjng that tastes good.  Ice cream is the only thing.  Probably because it freezes the tongue!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Mine hasnt come back between docetaxol!  But it maybe improves a bit.  I find wheat products the worse.  Same for me for Chtistmas dinner  . . .
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi. Just back from my appointment with the breast surgeon. The MRI shows that there has been a good partial response to the chemotherapy. The tumour is still 5cm but instead of being a solid mass it is now like a honeycomb. This is quite a normal response from a tumour that is not too aggressive apparently. But what this means is that i will have to have a full mastectomy and full clearance of all my lymph nodes. I will have a reconstruction at the same time as the surgery. This operation is not done in York but they have made me an appointment for 19th December at Castle Hill, Cottingham to see the surgeon there. Don't know the time yet. It is expected that surgery will happen between 12th and 31st January. There will be a number of tests that I will need prior to surgery to check that tummy fat is all healthy with good blood vessels for use to make a new breast. If i need work on the other breast to balance things up this will be done in York but at a later time. I am going ahead with my final chemotherapy on 12th December. Whether I need radiotherapy will depend on the testing of the diseased tissue. But belt and braces – probably. Then hormone tablets for 10 years. Not what I was hoping for – but the new breast will probably look better than one with a lump cut out of it. I will be in hospital for 3-5 days. Full recovery about 12 weeks but should start to feel better after 2 weeks and much better after 6 weeks.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: And now I am in a quandary! Just back from seeing oncologist to discuss chemo no 6. He says I don't need to have it if I don't want to. He is happy with the results of the 5 I have had. And he reminds me that each chemo is harder to deal with than the previous one. But the surgeon wants me to have surgery as close to 4 weeks after the last chemo as possible on the basis that the chemo stays in the body for 3 weeks – but my cancer is still there and so they want rid of it as soon as possible after chemo has finished. And i am already 2 weeks post chemo and appointment in 2 weeks time to start surgery process would take me to 4 weeks post chemo. Oncologist didn't seem worried about that but would see if he could get me an earlier appointment. But that would only be a week maximum. So if i don't have last chemo then surgery could be 6 – 8 weeks after last chemo rather than 4 – 6 weeks after last chemo. The surgeon says the last chemo may kill some more cells. The oncologist wasn't worried he was happy with what had been killed already. Surgeon gave impression she wants me to have last chemo. Oncologist not bothered. I asked why they targeted 6 chemo. Oncologist said they like to do a minimum of 4 but 6 is traditional! So now i don't know what to do. Have the last chemo or don't have the last chemo?
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I have made my decision re whether to have my originally planned 6th Chemo following my meeting with my oncologist yesterday.  After much soul searching I have decided not to have chemo 6.  I am still not recovered from  cnemo 5 and 6 is due in 5 days.  I have con luded that the in oncologist is right and my body has had enough.  One more treatment will not change my surgery plan and the 5 I have had should have destroyed any stray bits.  And i will be having radiotherapy. I aught to feel euphoric that this part is now over but am quute tearful and overwhelmed.  But I have had a nice day with a visit to my work and seeing my colleagues was so lovely.  And no I must get my body and mind stronger to face surgery and radiitherapy.  So more walking, more outings, more visiting - each day i hope to feel a little better.  And it is a relief to know I havent got to go through all the chemo joys again. Hope everyone is doing as well as you can and hugs and love to you all xxx

Fabulous xx

Posts.Title: living alone with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Pringle68 It depends!  It is a big operation and if everything goes according to plan you should be healed and starting to feel much better.  A lot of dancing may be difficult - but some possible. But things aren't always text book.  I am 14 weeks post right mastectomy, DIEP, with full node clearance.   Unfortunately I have had some problems and I am still not healed to the new breast.  Thin skin led to skin necrosis and i have a large open wound under my breast.  Skin grafts to be done in next couple of weeks so I can move onto radiotherapy.  I also have major fatigue issue but am beginning to suspect that Letrozole is contributing to this.  Been on Letrozole for 10 weeks now. I suggest you discuss with surgeon and his team - and you could wait a few weeks and see how quickly you recover. Good luck with op.  Fingers crossed you sail through.

Posts.Content: Violetsniff Your last sentence sums up my fears - frightened if they really know how I feel they will reject me because they don't know how to deal with it.  And even to an extent on this site.  I need people.  And therefore I will pretend its all fine in case people go away.
Posts.Title: Protecting others

Posts.Content: I've been wary about taking paracetomol all the time in case it masked a temperature.  And I did end up having bloods checked as I was runnj g a temperature - but had no obvious problem but just felt really poorly.  My bloods were OK so I then took paracetomol to help with unwell feelings.   I have had 2 docetaxol now and have not had any tingling in feet or hands.  My hair hasn't started growing though and my eyebrows and eyelashes are now disappearing. Still very tired and a bit achey but improving each day and feeling a bit more like myself.   And then it will be time for last one  . . . .
Posts.Title: First Docetaxal

Posts.Content: Hi Foxtrot I am a member of the two primary cancer club although my journey with first primary cancer was simple.  I was diagnosed with endometrial cancer in 2015.  My treatment was a full hysterectomy and bilateral oopherectomy.  Keyhole surgery and no chemo or radiotherapy!   Diagnosed with primary breast cancer in July 18.  Chemo (limited response), mastectomy with DIEP January 16th, radiotherapy to come once I have fully healed. I thought I'd had my turn.  I hope you're doing well xx
Posts.Title: 2 primary cancers in three and half years.

Posts.Content: Hi Mary4 Hope you are feeling a bit better.  If you still have sore throat and glands up you should maybe phone your chemo team.  They may want to check your bloods to rule out infection.  It may be viral but better to be safe than sorry.  Hope all well.
Posts.Title: First Docetaxal

Posts.Content: Hi.  Welcome to the group!  I haven't been in the same situation as you as I had to straight to mastectomy with reconstruction.  But for what it's worth I think I would now opt for mastectomy if I was in your shoes.  Then you know they have it all.   I had a DIEP reconstruction, not without problems - see profile, but the new boob does feel natural.  The LD flap is also very good and has a quicker recovery time.  And a lot of ladies are very happy with implants. What a blow though when you thought you had it all mapped out!  Cancer is like that and the curve balls catch us by surprise. Hugs and hope you can make your decision soon.  (I hate it when they give me a choice!).
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or re- excision?

Posts.Content: Hi Lellyv - it is worth checking with your breast care nurse re wigs.  A lot of health authorities in England give wig vouchers or an allowance towards a wig.  I am in York and was given a voucher to use at a wig shop for a NHS wig.  And there was a reasonable choice and the wig is very good.  No one knows it's a wig. Good luck with everything.   One step at a time .  Xx
Posts.Title: Chemo etc

Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone on Docetaxol.  Just a quick heads up.  I had my last chemo session (3EC and 2 docetaxel) 15 weeks ago and today the toe nail on my right pinkie came off.  I think my others are going to be ok.  And it isn't sore.  So the fall out from chemo may carry on slightly longer than expected!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Horsing Around So sorry you have been feeling nauseous.  And I'm afraid it is the anti sickness meds that cause the constipation.  But you DO need to take something for it or it could  be a real problem.  When mine wouldn't shift I phoned the chemk nurses and they prescribed Laxidol.  I also recently had Movicol in hospital.  I thjnk those names are right!  These didn't give me diarrhoea- but they really softened the stools so I could pass them.  Once I had this I started to use them the day before my EC and cintinued them until I had finished the anti sickness meds and then I was much better.   Hope it all eases soon xx
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi WeCanDoThis The 8 steroids before, on the day and day after are normal.  To help with side effects.  Although they of course have side effects - normally insomnia.    Anti sickness meds aren't normally needed for Docetaxol - it's kinder that way but has it's own little foibles.   I was lucky not to be sick with EC so while not easy I did find it easier than Docetaxol.  But if you suffered with sickness you may find that Docetaxol is easier for you. Hope it all goes well.  You are getting through it.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Mrs50 - well done on finishing chemo.  It is a nice feeliing isn't it?  Take it easy over the next few weeks.  I did it same order as you.  I am now 7 week post op and waiting to fully heal so i can start radiotherapy.  Good luck with your surgery.  But the hardest part done I think.

Posts.Title: Now got date for operation and I have some questions ....

Posts.Content: Hi everyone.  Back from hols today and as expected letter with date for my op - gulp - 16th January. I have had neo adjuvant chemo with a partial response but still need a full mastectomy.  So - full mastectomy, DIEP flap reconstruction and breast reduction to good boob - all planned for the one hit operation.  I have some silly questions for you ladies who have done it before me. I have ordered some front fastening post surgery bras in the size suggested by consultant - smaller than I am now.  Did you find front fastening easier to start with? PJs or nightie?  I normally wear PJs and thinking of getting some front fastening ones for easy access to wounds.  And easier to get on? Will I have a catheter when I wake.  If so would nightie be easier? I am having full node clearance so will getting clothes over my head be hard to start with? Sleeping - would a v shaped pillow help in the first few week?  I assume it will be hard to fully lie flat to start with? I'm asking hubby to take some time off when I come out of hospital.  As a general rule will a week be long enough?  He might drive me nutty if more than that! Also ordered some light support briefs. Anything I can do to prepare apart from trying not to panic and to keep walking! I will probably think of loads of other stuff.  MRI Monday, prep op Friday and then ok.   Many thanks in anticipation

Posts.Title: PALB2

Posts.Content: Touche - it depends.  And that isn't what you wanted to hear.   They told me at the clinic that mine was definitely cancer and the biopsies then confirmed the type and grade.  They should be able to tell you if it is just a cyst and therefore OK.  But I think there are some presentations that are not as clear one way or the other and need biopsy results. Fingers crossed for you tomorrow and I do hope all is well.  But if the news isn't what you had hoped for it is all still very treatable.   Hugs and best wishes x
Posts.Title: Appointment tomorrow

Posts.Content: Oh Touche.  What a shame you don't have a one stop shop yet.  More waiting.  Try and put it to the back of your mind.  Find lots of lovely things to do.  Meet friends and family and keel as busy as you can.  Whilst I was waiting I went to work and that did help distract me.  I didn't function at my best but it did help me. it is a week on Monday - if that makes it sound sooner?   I know it may not. Hugs and don't google! If it helps my consultant was 95% certain I had cancer just from feeling the lump - i went in to the mammogram and ultra sound already told it was cancer.  So if you haven't had that from consultant it could all still be OK. Xx

Posts.Content: Hi BugsFarm.  I too went for a short cut, a number 4, when my hair started falling out big time.  It was much easidr to manage the fallout then.  I am now 6 weeks post chemo and no sign of any regrowth yet.  I had 3 EC and 2T.  My body decided that 2 T was enough!
Posts.Title: Hair loss.

Posts.Content: I didnt lose all my eyebrows or lashes.  Bald patch in one eyebrow that i coloured in.  I lost some of my lashes but with eyeshadow underneath a but as well as lids and I don't think anyone noticed.
Posts.Title: Hair loss.

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs50 i took my temperature for a few days to see what was normal for me.  Then i only took it before taking paracetomol, if i had a headache for example, or if I felt a little unwell.    On my chemo 4 i woke at 4am one morning with really cold feet.  Over the next couple of hours I started to feel unwell and took my temperature every 15 minutes from 6.30 just to make sure first high temperature wasnt a fluke.  When temperature remained high and started to rise a little more I rang the number I had been given.  They asked me to go in and i was seen in onco outpatients and then admitted for 3 days. So my advice - see whats normal for you and then just take temperature if you feel someting could be wrong. All the best.

Posts.Content: A mixed days today and on reflection mainly good!  Feel like a list so here goes: It was dressing change day so that meant I could have a shower!  Bliss.  Wound is no worse. I drove my car for the first time since op!  And it was fine.  Independence back!  That should help me so much Went for my walk with slightly increased distance and no foot problems today The sun is shining The not so good - went to ? M and S to change a bra.  Staff were lovely but I ended up in tears.  Every little thing and I am in tears these days.  So embarrasing. The ducks were on our local swale today - swale takes the water from our roofs when it rains and is thus a Sustainable Drainage System (SUDS) scheme.  (Sorry got my professional work hat on there).

Posts.Content: Sunnyone - what beautiful fruit and veg.  The purple sprouting broccoli is one of my favourites.  Do hope work not tiring you out too much. moomy - hope you enjoyed your walk down the cut.  My Mum and Dad loved the canals and at one time had there own narrow boat.  My 92 year old Mum still takes her holidays on the canals.  There are a few hotel boats that take guests and cruise them around.  Mum usually has 3 of these a year but just one this year and thinks this may have to be her last due to mobility issues.  But if we can find a way for next year we will. I didn't make my 5500 steps yesterday - was about 800 short.  Hubby was home and I don't potter about so much when he is home.  But have done it today.  My visitor this morning had to cancel so I went bra shopping (yet again!l this morning and then dragged myself out for my one mile walk this afternoon.  No nice pics today as the walk was very urban around housing estates.  Need to go out early tomorrow as popping in to work for a catch up over lunch and then hospital in afternoon.  Will seem strange when I can't call in at work anymore (I am retiring on 31st May). Think it's going to be wet tomorrow folks - take your brollies
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Well  . . .   Going to meet 2 lovely friends in town and decided to make an effort.  Put on my bargain dress and my only just not flat shoes.  Started walking to the bus stop and so unsteady i fell over.  And couldn't get up.  A kind delivery man stopped and helped me.  So back home to change into totally flat boots and managed to walk to bus stop and meet my friends.  A few grazes but nothing major.  But so unsteady on pins at moment - not sure if just still recovering or if the dreaded Letrozole playing havoc.  Had a lovely catch up with friends and got home with no further mishaps.  And cracked my 5500 step target.   Away with 2 work friends for weekend tomorrow.  Near lakedistrict.  Tempted to buy a walking stick to help with stability!  For goodness sake - I'm only 62.  This will NOT beat me.  (Having blood tests next week to rule out other issues - GP testing for everything!  Never met him but we had a nice chat on the phone yesterday). Is it nice to be home Moomy?  The canal looks lovely. Violetsniff - so glad you are enjoying the gym Everyone else who is doing lovely stuff - wonderful.  Enjoy it all.

Posts.Content: Fabulous Sunnyone
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: No particular walks for the last few days although apart from today, when I visited 92 year old Mum, i have achieved my 6000 steps a day target.   Friday saw an emergency trip to hospital as PICO dressing was being very efficient but was full after a day and a half.  So new one applied and seems to have settled down.  So that day was hospital walking and general pottering. Saturday was quite fun - looking for a hat for the Royal Garden Party.  Didn't find one but was fun trying hats and fascinators on.  Decided I don't like fascinators.  Not many hats in shops (apart from specialist shop when they were £250 a hat).  So ordered one on line from Debenhams (£30).  If it's no good i can take it back.  So retail walking. Took Mum out for lunch today - she lives 80 miles away.  Her car has given up the ghost and she needed to decide whether to get a new one - at 92!.  I think she has decided not but is struggling with some of the independence she will lose.  Taking her to look at mobility scooters in a couple of weeks - that might improve her quality of life as we could put in our car and we could have a trip to the seaside which she hasn't been able to do due to poor mobility and a fierce pride. Lots of lovely walks from you all this weekend - well done.  Lovely to see.  Keeping my target at 6000 for another week at least - don't think I can do any more whilst I have this awful wound issue. Hope you all have a lovely week ahead xx

Posts.Content: A lovely day for sitting outside Violetsniff.  And your embroidery looks beautiful.  You are very talented.

Posts.Content: A short walk around the gardens at my local NT property.  The Magnolias in full bloom and full scent.  Hope you have all had a lovely weekend xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hospital dressing clinic based walks today.  Then into Beverley to meet youngest son for lunch - he was a cheap date today.  Both our lunches and drinks came to £10! Yet another regime for wound.  Saw the dressing nurse today who doesn't like tacky dressings.  She thinks the PICO has done it's job, all well granulated and I know need non tacky dressings to change every other day, shower well on dressing change day and leave to air for a couple of hours if possible.   Airing partly for skin around wound as 12 weeks of sticky dressings has made me sore in places.  Appointment a week on Wednesday so the surgeon can come in and see progress (?).  I must admit I don't like tacky dressings as feel they pull off new formed skin when you change them.  The progress i had achieved was lost when the surgeon recommended tacky dressings.  My dressings box is overfliwing with various attempts at a suitable dressings! Very fed up - I feel as though no progress in 12 weeks. No photos today - but sun is shining outside and the roadside hedges are all coming to life.  Hope you have all managed to enjoy some fresh air and sunshine today xx

Posts.Content: seaspirit44 - how could J forget your swimming.  Webbed gloves - now there's a thing.!  When I am fit J think I will visit our gym that has an outdoor pool as ut sounds so wonderful xx

Posts.Content: Hi moomy.  Back at dressings clinic on Wednesday and they will call the plastic surgeon in.  I am going to try and pin the surgeon down to talk to me properly - must not cry.  Not always easy as I am naked from the waist up.  Had to change dressing at Mum's yesterday afternoon as it was full.  Also got the issue of all the tape used to hold dressings in place has given me sores.  I'm putting Savlon on them which is helping.  Must remember to ask about Mannukah honey as well.   My lovely friend Simon came this afternoon and we walked to cake shop for a cuppa and a scone.  And he is going to start organising a room and food for my retirement thing.  Which is lovely of him.   Lovely sunshine here today xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi seaspirit44.  Plastic surgeon next Wednesday.   Not an appointment with him but dressings nurses have timed my dressings appointment for when he does outpatients.  Then they go and get him when my wound is exposed.   I am going to try and have a list of questions and try and explain how awful this is.  It is difficult as I am half naked and he is in a rush.  But I need help.  I can't go on like this for much longer. Family weekend ahead including my lovely 18 month old grandson.   Hoping for cuddles but he is very lively! Swimming sounds wonderful.  Very jealous xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Back from hospital.   Held it together reasonably well considering not feeling great; as as well as healing I have a cold and a UTI!  Never had a UTI before - I'm blaming Letrozole.  Phoned GP yesterday and she prescribed antibiotics over the phone.  Improving. Anyway - got distracted there!  We have decided to do a skin graft next week or the week after.   He needs to look at his list and see where he can squeeze me in.  Local anaesthetic.  So fingers crossed this works.  Then nurse decides that she will put some jelonet with gauze on the wound and my "snug" bra will hold it in place.  I did tell her it wasn't that snug as F cup one side and B cup the other . . .   So got home and guess what dressing had slipped; bra stained with blood.  So luckily I have a box of various dressings from the last 13 weeks and i have dressed with the most comfortable dressings I have and ordered some more from gp surgery.  I will do my own thing with wound until I have the graft. Still got no energy, get breathless and legs very heavy.  But lets get healed, then I can start radiotherapy and once that is done I will try and sort out everything else.  I reckon it will be end of May before radiotherapy starts.  Not much walking being done but I have decided not to push myself at the moment.  I will try and get out though for the sake of my mental health.   I could do with a Little Henry moomy! Enjoy the lovely weather everyone.

Posts.Content: . . . Found the thrush Moomy  . . . .  Lovely pics
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Well . . ..  . Phone rang at 12.15.  It was the hospital to say they had been expecting me at 12 for my skin graft today!  No telephine calls or letters telling me about this!  I am an hour away from hospital but agreed to drop everything, drag husband away from preparing for his golf holiday tomorrow to drive me there and back and got to hospital by 2pm.   So I have had my skin graft done under a local anaesthetic.  Didn't take long - took me to theatre at 4.10 and back at 4.50.  So i now have a huge plaster on my leg and another on my breast.  Back next Tuesday to check boob.  Dressing stays on leg for 2 weeks undisturbed.  No pain at moment, think I may still be numb! Can't drive for a week.  On my own for 3 days from tomorrow.   I was hoping to take myself for treats.  But guess it is binge TV - certainly tomorrow.    Love everyone's pics.  Was planning a Bluebell visit this afternoon - but at least I can see them in your pics. Enjoy your walks xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: My walking confined to house today.  Walked round kitchen and made fridge soup (whatever stray vegies are in the fridge that need using up).  Then will walk round jigsaw puzzle! Met colleagues for lunch yesterday as part of my retirement farewells (I am having a few such sessions). But it did make me very sad.  My management team - so the people i worked so closely with.  But my replacement is doing a good job, differently from how I would do things (but that's fine), and the office didn't fall apart because I haven't been there.  I put it down to my leadership having got things into such a good state!  But I will miss them and it was lovely to see them all together and have a nice social lunch.  And my hair is now longer than most of them.  Mind you two are quite bald, one shaves his and the other two probably still have longer hair than me!  (All men).  But I did feel quite down as I left them.  Normal I suppose.  The end of such an important part of my life.  Work was my job, my hobby, my life challenges - and I did enjoy it so much.  It gave me such a buzz to be involved in exciting projects, to work with such talented people, and to lead a team that achieved fantastic results which were recognised nationally within the industry.   I am meeting up with the colleagues I did a masters degree with (we graduated 2 and a half years ago with me by far the oldest in the group at turned 60 then - i was honoured that work sponsored me at such an old age!) for an evening get together next wednesday.  Alcohol will be involved with these 30 and 40 year olds!  So i have booked a hotel.  Then the following day I am having lunch with my head of service and my management peers.  Then on the 24th is my formal leaving do where there will no doubt be speeches etc!  I have my dear mate Simon lined up to pull funny faces at me so i don't cry!  Then the pub and then a few of us will grab a pizza.  Then that will be it (although retirement day actually 31st May).  It will feel so strange. Sorry - that was a bit of a waffle on about my retirement!  And in the middle of all those events is my trip down to London for the Royal Garden Party!  Hopefully you are all well xx

Posts.Content: Morning everyone.  I am new to this thread - stepping across from the chemo threads.  My chemo is now finished and surgery and radiotheraoy ahead of me.   Although I am 4 weeks since my last chemo I am still suffering with fatigue and putting one foot in front of the other is an effort.  And put a slight incline in my way and the effort is doubled.  So I am starting on a walk every day.  Try to increase my stamina and get fit for surgery.  This plan is now even more relevant following my appointment with surgeon to plan my surgery yesterday (full mastectomy and node clearance to right breast with DIEP flap reconstruction and breast reduction to left side to balance things up.  All at same time) and the surgeon would like me to lose half a stone before surgery if possible.  I have piled weight on during chemo - comfort eating even though things tasted weird and then finding sweet stuff tasted best.  So i had planned to start losing weight after Christmas but need to make an effort before, now.    Difficult at this time of year though.  So can I share my fitness journey with you all?  I love seeing your walks and you are all succeeding and doing so well. My plans for today - waiting for microwave repair man this morning but if he comes early i will walk to local Aldi to pick up salmon and salad.  10 mins walk each way.  Then I have a cake date this afternoon (so not going to have lunch  . . . ).  And walk to Cake D'Licious (lovely name for a tea room) is about 15 minutes each way.  And i will use the upstairs loo rather than the downstairs one (every little helps!). Hope you all enjoy your walks today and when I go somewhere more exciting I will share pictures (in Whitby for new year).

Plumber coming tomorrow to try and sort heating so will ice christmas cakes whilst he is here.  Then planning to drive the car closer to York centre and then go for a walk.  I live close enoigh to walk in when fitter (about a mile and a half).  But bit at a time.   Happy strolling tomorrow everyone

Posts.Content: Gosh it was hard putting one foot in front of the other this afternoon.  By the time I had walked half a mile I was struggling - and of course there is the half mile back again!  But no pain no gain so they say.  Weather was lovely though and the river looked calm and pretty.  Only managed a total of 5800 steps today.  But keep trying. Posts.Content: Glad you're all getting exercise in its many forms. I'm still taking it easy and trying to heal.  Got my histology results and ongoing plan today.  They found DCIS as well as 5cm tumour but have clear margi s in mastectomy.  So planning radiotherapy to chest wall and neck nodes to make sure nothing lurking there.  And the dreaded Letrozole and oseoprosis drugs but can't remember what they are called.  Can't start them until dental check up and treatment.  And that will have to wait until I feel better.  Couldn't cope with dental treatment for a few weeks.  Radiotherapy can't start until I've healed.   Could be 6 weeks.  Saw nurse about wounds and she cut away lots of dead skin and cleaned up and assured me not infected.  But still bleeding and a long way to go.  Quite distressing.  Go back next Friday. Anyway following your walks with interest and enjoyment.  Keep voi g and hopefully in 6 weeks I will be walming with you inbetween radiotherapy sessions.

Posts.Content: Hi Sunnyone - your friend sounds amazing.  I too think I should have more energy.  Shouldn't my legs not feel as though they  weigh100lbs each? Healing is still slow.  Saw the plastic surgeon yesterday and he thinks it will heal.  But seeing him again next week to assess progress and make decisions as to whether to go for skin grafts.  He wasn't happy with the dressing regime and I felt it was my fault.  But I had been doing as instructed by the plastic team dressing nurses.  So he told me I needed to get dressings checked at gp practice on Friday and put a different dressing on.  But couldn't give me any spares.  So I made appointment for Friday but woke up this morning with dressing soaked through with blood and leaking.   So phoned gp and got an emergency dressing appointment and saw a lovely nurse.  She cleaned it all up, measured wounds so we can record progress, redressed it.  Wrote me a prescription for spare dressings and arranged to see me in a week so she can give me some more support through this.  And then gave me a hug! Not at my usual practice and in centre of York with no parking but she was so lovely I will go back for continuity.   Have seen 5 different nurses at hospital - and they are lovely too but no continuity.   Sorry - that rambled on.  You only asked how the healing was! But I am persevering with moving and have exceeded my 4000 step target every day.  Hope going back to work is not wearing you out - take it easy. Keep going everyone - we can do it.

Hope you are all keeping your spirits up and your legs walking xx

Posts.Content: Was at hospital this afternoon for check on graft.  Nurse thinks it has taken!  There was an area with fluid under but she thinks that may be where there is skin underneath.  She lanced it to get rid of it anyway.   Redressed it and back next week when they will also check on leg (which they didn't do today as it is left undisturbed for 2 weeks).  So fingers crossed we have crossed a checkpoint and by next week graft will defunitely have taken.  See the plastic surgeon in two weeks when I hope he will give the go ahead for radiotherapy to begin.  Do hope all ok. Very emotional at moment.  Rang GP surgery to make an appointment for a face to face consultation re fatigue, leg/foot/ankle that not working, insomnia, etc etc.  Receptionist was very nice but no normal appointments were available with any doctor in the 4 week period they have open for appointments.  And I just burst into tears.  So she has given me an urgent appointment for next Tuesday.  Didn't mean the water works to give me special  treatment.   Think she was worried about me as she said don't forget we are here and if you need to speak to a doctor just ring and She would get one to phone me. Very nice lady.  But I do need a face to face as how do you show how your foot and ankle don't move over the phone! Anyway got a few nice things planned for the next few days - no real walking as I am only to potter.  But will potter to the bus and from bus to cafe to meet some friends timorrow and friday.  Then going to see Mum on Saturday.  Hardwick Inn again for lunch Moomy. Happy hols, walking, exercising, crafting, gardening etc everyone xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi.  Not sure where to post this up date!  Not really walking related - apart from problems stopping me walking! So. Went to see GP today with a number of issues.  First - foot drop.  GP referred me for an urgent brain scan to rule out problem caused by secondaries in brain.  We both think that all will be clear and most likley cause -  chemo or trauma from operation.   Once brain proves to be clear then she will refer me for specialist physio.  In the meantime I will start some exercises I have found on a reputable source on the net.   Nothing to lose. Second - fatigue.  Thinks this is most likely Letrozole related.   But doing some more blood tests.  If these come back OK then to ring breast care nurse and seek an appointment with consultant.   I told her I couldn't be like this for 10 years.  She also said still early days and foot drop, healing, anxiety, stress can all cause fatigue and that it was early days.   Emotions - all over the place.  But she thinks I am dealing with it normally.  Yes very tearful at the drop of a hat but so much to deal with.  I am doing the right thing in trying to plan things to look forward to every day.  But if the world starts turnjng black then to go back and she would prescribe anti depressants. Hospital tomorrow to check wound . . . .  Hope you all had a lovely bank holiday weekend. Xx

Posts.Content: New week.  New step goal.  4000 steps a day this week.  Been out for my walk and walked furthest I have since surgery.  1.1 miles at a pace of 25 minutes per mile.  Not quite fast enough for your washing cycle Moomy!  Legs still feel heavy and lead like.  But persevere. Tried to make an appointment with GP today.  Haven't seen one since diagnosis in July.   Can't get one before my meds run out.  Oncologist only prescribed 28 days supply and letter to GP only came through on Friday.  Maybe should have made appointment before letter came.  So I have a telephone appointment a week on Wednesday - the earliest they could do.  Never been one to go to doctor and when I have needed help it has been of the I need to see a doctor urgently variety and then got a same day appointment.  Both these times it turned out I had cancer - endometrial and then breast.  So a bit of a shock how difficult it is to get a routine appointment to discuss drugs and ongoing support. Oh well.  The sun is shining and my fit bit says I have done 3000 of my 4000 steps.  May be trickg getting another 1000 in pottering around the house  . . . ..  Have a good week everyone x

Posts.Content: Hi seaspirit44.  Hope you are improving healthwise both physically and mentally.  It's a tough gig this isn't it? The garden party is in May.  There are 3 dates and we have stated our prefefence for 21st May - but of course will go whichever date we get.  I was told I was going to be invited on the day of my op - 16th January.  And I thought all active treatment would have been completed and I would be well on road to my new normal.  Things delayed due to this blasted wound.  But the treatment dates will have to work around the garden party date - i will never have this opportunity again.  I work for local government (although I am now retiring on 31st May) and the council get a place to nominate someone each year.  And this year they have chosen me!  A very kind and thoughful gesture as I have been off sick since mid Auguest.  And I am sure the invite would not have come my way if I hadn't been ill.  But I am very proud that they think enough of me to do this for me at such a difficult time in my life. I do hope we can take some pics in the palace grounds and I am looking forward to people thinking I must be famous as I queue up to go in.

Posts.Content: Lovely walks everyone!   I've not been out and about for a week or so.  Had skin graft on Tuesday and donor site, upper thigh,  is quite sore when I move around so haven't been doing a lot.  Certainly no walks or therpeutic scones HappyFeet1.  But eldest son and 18 month old grandskn been for weekend whilst daughter in law had a girly weekend.  Lovely to see them.  I had very sjmple meals delivered from Ocado so it was easy for me.  Hubby was away for 3 days immediately following graft so I didn't have to cook for him or anything for 3 days followjng graft.  He is a bit thoughtless though.  As he left he hoped I would be OK and said contact him if I needed him.  Fine so far!  Then never heard a dicky bird from him till he got back at 9pm Friday night.  A text would have been nice.  MEN!  Anyway grandson was delightful and ate and slept all at the correct times.   Next week sees hospital visit to check on ba*ra*d boob as I now call it.  Leg doesn't get checked for 2 weeks.  Lets hope this works and I can get back to some walks and pics and radiotherapy can start. Enjoying your visits, walks, stories - keep it up and I'll join in properly again soon.

Posts.Content: Lovely pictures and walks everyone.  And dodging the showers!  Well done. My mobility is stopping me getting out much - particularly on my own.  I am losing confidence.   So i have swallowed my pride and ordered a rollator to help me get about outside.  At least i will be able to sit when i need to and it will take the pressure off my arm.  I need to use a stick in my right arm which is the one where axillary  clearance and so I am concerned about the strain on it.  Start radiotherapy in a couple of weeks and so lymphoedema risk increases.  I do hope they can sort my foot drop out but won't be a quick process I'm sure - haven't even got a physio appointment yet! (MRI showed no brain mets - hooray!). Hubby out at least 4 days a week playing golf and then has household chores and gardening so apart from taking me to see my mum every 2 weeks he doesn't have time to take me out.  Changing my car for an automatic so driving is easier and safer (left leg gammy).  I am trying so hard to look after my mental health by being determined and getting out a bit.   So hope it helps!  I will feel very self conscious.  But i will get out and about.  For goodness sake there is only so much homes under the hammer a woman can take . . . . . Keep the pics coming and I hope to get out more soon (in between radiotherapy!)

Posts.Content: Went out with a friend today for a pub lunch and then down to the river to the big lock (left camera in car!).  Very pleased to say that Willy Wonka (Moomy the walker has been christened) was a great help.  Even took it off road across uneven grass which I can't contemplate with just a stick.  Didn't go far but GOT OUT!  And my new automatic car is easier too.  Willy Wonka is fairly stylish too. Saw GP on Tuesday and just had a call from her.  She has spoken to my oncologist who thinks my mobility is probably not cancer related but ti have a spine bone scan to rule out spine mets.  And then if this OK then refer me to a neurologist.  We are all agreed that physio shouldn't be done until we know the cause.  I have no pain just immobility and weakness.  Quite typical of onset multiple sclerosis but it would be bloody unlucky if this was the case!  I'm sure it's not.  Just glad doctor is taking it seriously.  It has coincided with taking Letrozole so I am not convinced it is unrelated.  But we have to investigate.  I like a good puzzle and problem solving - but not this way lol. Going out again tomorrow to meet a friend at a food fayre in Helmsley.  Me and Willy Wonka will be good to go. Enjiy the nice weather everyone xx

Posts.Title: Scans - neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Oh Londonmumof2.  Such a tough time.  Huge hugs. Try and take some comfort in that nodes affected doesn't always mean it spread.  I had 4 nodes affected and haven't been offered any scans for spread - when I asked they said it wasn't necessary.  The nodes are the filter for the bad stuff.  So they catch the nasties and deal with them before they slip past.   And take support from those lovely colleagues and friends.  Ignore those who can't support you.   Do keep posting on this site.  It does help to know that there are people here who really understand.  We are all with you, all the way, for however long you need us.  And everyone of us is different.  And we are all getting through treatment somehow.  And you will too.  But please do seek professional support - there is lots out there.  I am just starting to ask for help some 9 minths after diagnosis (i am stillmin treatment) but should have done this sooner.  So don't be afraid to admit you need help - and ask for it. Huge hugs

But I think a SE of Letrozole as symptoms started when I started taking tablets.  Speaking to BCN about a break so this can be ruled out or in.  Wondered if your problem could be related to Letrozole or the like?
Posts.Title: Neuropathy in hips and back

Posts.Content: Hi.  Might be worth going to GP as those pains could be symptomatic of hip degeneration.  They sound similar to what my Mum had before she had a new hip.  Worth checking?
Posts.Title: Neuropathy in hips and back

Posts.Content: Hi Lulu.  Have they given you the syringes with the springs that automatically retract?  I had these and found them easier than I thought.  I pinched some flesh on my tummy and then gently but firmly pushed the needle in - straight down.  When in i then pressed the plunger and when fully down it automatically retracted and the needle was out.   I took them out of the fridge 45 minutes before i used them. I wasn't given antiseptic wipes.  But if you are make sure that the area is dry after use before injecting otherwise it can sting.  I found a couple of videos on you tube that helped. It was easier than i expected  . . . .
Posts.Title: advice on giving injections after chemo

Posts.Content: Good luck kathleen37.  You can do this and really good to have something to focus on that isn't cancer.  Inbetween my cancer bouts (the first was womb and no treatment apart from op) I lost five and a half stone on Slimming World.  I'm afraid I have put two and a half stone back on - one and a half during chemo.  So when my treatment is finished ( radiotherapy still to come) I will be trying to shift the excess weight.   Take it a pound at a time and in 6 months you will be a couple of stone lighter I'm sure.  Good luck and look forward to a new wardrobe ...

Posts.Content: Hi A recent blood test identified that I have very low vit d levels and have been prescribed a 6 week course of boosts.  Level was 21.  No idea on levels pre cancer.  Haven't noticed any improvement on fatigue levels or with healing since taking.  I am half way through my 6 week course. Xx
Posts.Title: vitamin D - who knows their vitamin D levels are low ?

Posts.Content: Hi Jsteph You are not alone with these feelings.   A lot of us feel like this.   Much as our loved ones try to help they don't truly understand.   And we spend a lot of time trying to protect them.  And we spend a lot of time alone,  My family and friends all work and so most of the time I am alone and lonely.   I had a busy, challenging and fulfilling job before cancer and I have been off work 6 months now.  To go from that to being alone most of the time and trying to cope with cancer, changing treatment plans (mine changed from "just" a mastectomy to chemo, mastectomy with DIEP,  radiotherapy to come, hormone treatment  . . . ) is not easy.  But you are not alone.   Post on this site and you will find support.  Not quite the same as meeting a friend for coffee or wine but it does help.  I'm currently trying to get my head round gettting out of bed, getting dressed and doing something.   The sun is shining and J am sure a short walk (I am 5 weeks post DIEP with some boob healing issues) will help lift the spirits. We are with you all the way.
